You, my friend, need a different job. Unless of course you'd rather take the risks and keep the big bucks. If that's it then don't whine about the risks.
"Urban stop light?" Most people would just say "red light."

I do this job because I want to bring progress to the 3rd world. The cellular networks I work on allow people in Africa, South and Central America, and South Asia to emerge from poverty on their own initiative.

When I tell cab drivers and hotel employees in relatively more secure countries why I am in their nation, they pickup and wave their cell phones and beam.

I get smiles, and hugs, and free cab rides, and extra amenities in my hotel room. When I tell people in the US, they only complain about their Cell provider. You can keep your money.

As a network engineer deployed to the 3rd world, I sometimes go to work with "close protection". In one country, in an armored vehicle with 3 ex-military holding automatic weapons "off safety". This was after the engineers I replaced were dragged out of their vehicle and executed while stopped and trapped at an urban stop light.

I can't refuse these assignments if I want to keep my job. I don't know if the company separately insures me with their name as the beneficiary. I do know that they don't subsidize the extra insurance that I pay for myself in recognition of the sometimes dangerous conditions in which I work.

If you read the article, you'd know that Prof. K isn't "touting" second-rate solutions. He's accepting them as a possibly inevitable alternative to first-rate solutions.

G-- forbid that Fred Dworsky should be inconvenienced in order to save the planet from a 10-degree (F) rise in temperature within a few generations (a less likely outcome than a lesser rise, but extremely dangerous to civilization).

Pardon me, Fred Dorbsky, haste makes errors.

The second best ideas, if the first best can't be pushed through the defense line of private industry, are needed. It is quite clear from reading the news and from climatological research that the danger from global warming to the survival of civilization is real. It might not happen. So (as they say) cancel your home insurance. You might not have a problem.

The "second-best" solutions that Prof. Krugman touts in his column are all second-rate pursuits. First, he calls for putting the government on the backs of all of us through micromanagement style regulation. Second, Prof. Krugman recommends using crony capitalism to reward friendly companies with tax payer guaranteed loans. Finally he supports a cap-and-trade system that would reward private parties instead of allowing the government to collect the revenues.

Americans should insist on the first rate solution of a greenhouse gas emissions tax, and not settle for the so-called second best ideas that could do more harm than good in the long run.

With or without a carbon tax, fossil fuels might be having their last hoorah. Solar cell and fuel cell technologies are rapidly coming down in price, and in the next few decades renewable energy will likely be much cheaper than fossil fuels. Although a greenhouse gas emissions tax could greatly hasten the process, such intervention might not be necessary to save the earth from catastrophe.

Steve, diagnosis of mental illness is a complex process that usually leaves patients with several diagnoses over the years, from several providers.
This is because symptoms overlap between disorders, and not all symptoms present in each episode of illness.
It is also because of rapid advances in research of brain disorders. Brain disorders and human sexuality are the last taboo frontiers of medicine, and are finally getting the attention they need.
That said, it took how many years for Western medicine to figure out treatments for simple infections, let alone cancer, heart disease, diabetes, and now, mental illness? Devising ways to positively identify the illnesses was the first step, then treatment, and maybe, eventually, cure.
Right now, the best way to positively identify mental illness is to wait and watch, and sometimes we get lucky when an illness responds in a unique way to medication (i.e. the typical manic response to antidepressants in patients with bipolar disorder.)

As a "foreigner" and non-US citiizen, who teacher "special" students and has lived here for more than 20 years, I am struck by the magnitude of this problem. I am seeing more and more children at an incredibly young age treated with medication to control symptoms caused by their environment and parents ill equipped or incapable of supplying adequate care and nurturing( to put it bluntly). In my home country the supports offered for working parents and the prevailing attitude that one parent staying home with babies and very young children for the first 2 years is of enormous benefit to both child and parent ( and ultimately society) . Government sponsored/run day care centers where personnel with degreed and/or similar programs in early education work for adequate pay are available with costs tailored to income tare offered after the initial years. My experience in teaching in my home country is that these investments pay off in real terms of fewer children having the magnitude of mental issues that I see here. I have seen students in pre-school and kindergarten that were put on medication to control behavior due to parental problems and their numbers are increasing. The parents often feel helpless and have nowhere to turn to that effectively helps them and their children.
While there are programs in place where caring impact workers, social workers, etc are trying to address the problems they are confronted with, it often seems to little too late,

Response to Richard Head: No. That's not the idea. Turn the question around: how much temptation to lose money should we put in front of the entire population? The fact is that the impact of losing money is far greater on the lower income population, just as is the desire for some hope, any hope, of being delivered from the conditions brought about by poverty and near poverty.

Most studies that I have heard of indicate that lower income people are the most likely to play the lottery. Why? Because the idea of risking a few dollars and getting millions back is very enticing. If one has no prospect of ever seeing any level of prosperity and the comfort it might bring, then the lottery has more appeal. To someone making hundreds of thousands a year, the lottery would represent little in terms of life style change (unless they used it to quit their job, etc.), but to the near poor, it would, for a brief moment, seem like being in heaven to be removed from constant concerns about having enough money.

Here's the question: should we encourage business organizations that have as their primary purpose taking money from the poor? Many states have passed laws limiting payday lenders and other schemes that are fully designed to prey on those with little money and no credit.

Gambling can be an addictive habit for rich and poor. How much do we want it to be everywhere, all the time, always available?

I have to say it`s a strange but very telling moment when the most popular of the `NYT picks` comments, misses the point entirely.  Krugman correctly and clearly pointed out here that Henry Paulson didn`t argue for a cap-and-trade mechanism in his editorial, but Paulson did argue for a carbon tax.  The latter is in many economists` view much more efficient and effective to the purpose of actually reducing emissions, while spurring investment and the happy side effects thereof.

You are confusing two distinct methods of reducing carbon emissions: (1) a carbon tax (advocated by Paulson); and (2) a cap-and-system (discussed in Rolling Stone).  Under a carbon tax, there are no credits to trade--no market for carbon permits.  Perhaps you should run a correction to your comment...

Goldman Sachs, which Paulson used to run and which he helped bail out at our expense, stands to profit big-time from carbon credit trading.

Whenever a free market guru mentions "innovation" and concern for the planet in the same breath, the bait and switch alarm bells should be ringing in your head.

Instead, Paulson is lauded for courageously breaking away from right-wing nuttery, simply by deigning to believe in man-made global warming.

As Matt Taibbi wrote some years ago in his now-famous "Vampire Squid" magazine piece, Goldman Sachs has long been anxious to blow up the carbon tax bubble:

"The new carbon credit market is a virtual repeat of the commodities-market casino that's been kind to Goldman, except it has one delicious new wrinkle: If the plan goes forward as expected, the rise in prices will be government-mandated. Goldman won't even have to rig the game. It will be rigged in advance."

If polluters go over emission limits, they'll be able to buy credits from the more compliant companies. Then the financial predators will corner the market on the ever-scarcer credits, and stand to make as much as a trillion dollars... a year:

http://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/the-great-american-bubble-mach...

So, if you believe that Paulson wrote his op-ed purely out of altruistic concern for your lungs, I'd say I have a bridge to sell you, except that it's probably already been privatized and plundered by the financial mafia. Call it GoldmanCare.

So while I'd prefer single payer healthcare for many reasons, I am glad we've improved access to healthcare for many.
